ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: A range of basic microwave skills. See syllabus.
Basic understanding of transmission lines, waveguides, scattering matrices, and some passive components (couplers, splitters)
My first exposure to RF circuits, so I learned a ton.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The course is pretty much perfect. Perhaps more classroom demonstrations?
I wish there had been more HW's. I personally learn by doing so more would have been helpful. The final project increased my knowledge of the class material by a lot. It was a great experience.

The biggest (and pretty much only) problem with the course was the room in which it was located. It was too small and too hot (nearly 80 degrees F) for me to pay attention. It was also structured in a way that seemed to maximize mean distance from the blackboard. A couple of more homework assignments would've been good to get some more practice on some things. Or maybe have two projects: one more guided or uniform for the entire class and a final one that is the students' choice.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: yes! I feel like I have a better handle on a lot of the techniques I will be using in research. This was the most relevant class I've taken at Yale.
Yes, if you need to use microwave components in your research and want a good foundation
Yes. Project at the end was the best part.
